items.title_orig: Pakistan warns of ‚Äòdangerous escalation‚Äô as UNHRC urges accountability for Israel‚Äôs Qatar attack
items.summary_orig: Pakistan warned of ‚Äúdangerous escalation‚Äù as the United Nations and a long line of countries on Tuesday denounced Israel‚Äôs attack on Qatar last week, demanding ‚Äúaccountability‚Äù. Israel‚Äôs strikes on the Qatari capital on September 9 targeted Hamas leaders gathered to discuss a new US ceasefire proposal for Gaza. Five Hamas members and a Qatari security officer were killed. That strike ‚Äúwas a shocking breach of international law‚Äù, UN rights chief Volker Turk said during an urgent debate at the UN Human Rights Council about the strike. Denouncing the attack as ‚Äúan assault on regional peace and stability‚Äù, he urged ‚Äúaccountability for unlawful killings‚Äù. His words were echoed by Qatar and dozens of country representatives who took the floor during the three-hour debate. Qatari International Cooperation Minister Maryam bint Ali bin Nasser Al-Misnad slammed Israel‚Äôs ‚Äútreacherous attack‚Äù and demanded that the international community ‚Äútake practical steps to hold the aggressors accountable and prevent their impunity‚Äù. ‚ÄúThis attack was not an isolated incident, but rather was part of a broader campaign aimed at distorting Qatar‚Äôs role and obstructing its diplomatic efforts,‚Äù she said. Pakistan‚Äôs ambassador Bilal Ahmad warned that ‚Äúthis unjustifiable and unprovoked attack constitutes a dangerous escalation‚Äù. The council had announced on Monday that it would convene the 10th urgent debate since its creation in 2006, following two official requests from members of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation and of the Gulf Cooperation Council. Pakistan was among those that led the call for the urgent debate. ‚ÄòShameful‚Äô Neither Israel nor its main ally, the United States, which both disengaged from the council earlier this year, was present for the urgent debate. But Israel‚Äôs ambassador in Geneva, Daniel Meron, lambasted the meeting from the sidelines. ‚ÄúThis marks yet another shameful chapter in the Human Rights Council‚Äôs ongoing abuse,‚Äù he told journalists. He accused the council of ‚Äúserving as a platform for anti-Israel propaganda, while ignoring the brutal realities on the ground and the atrocities committed by Hamas‚Äù. There was little support for Israel‚Äôs position during the debate. European Union ambassador Deike Potzel stressed the bloc‚Äôs ‚Äúprincipled stance against terrorism in all its forms‚Äù, while underlining its ‚Äúsupport for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Qatar‚Äù and calling ‚Äúon Israel to respect international law‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe urge all parties to refrain from any actions that jeopardise mediation channels and regional stability,‚Äù she said. China‚Äôs ambassador Chen Xu said his country ‚Äúfirmly rejects and categorically condemns‚Äù the September 9 attack, which he charged was ‚Äúa deliberate attempt to derail the negotiation process‚Äù. Some of the harshest criticism came from South Africa, which has brought a case against Israel before the International Court of Justice, accusing it of committing genocide in Gaza. The attack ‚Äústrikes against the very heart of mediation processes‚Äù, ambassador Mxolisi Nkosi told the council, adding that it ‚Äúdemonstrates that Israel does not want to end its genocidal war against the Palestinian people‚Äù. ‚ÄúIt is time for the international community to demonstrate through practical countermeasures that Israel does not enjoy some form of special immunity from accountability.‚Äú
items.title_en: Pakistan warns of ‚Äòdangerous escalation‚Äô as UNHRC urges accountability for Israel‚Äôs Qatar attack
items.summary_en: Pakistan warned of ‚Äúdangerous escalation‚Äù as the United Nations and a long line of countries on Tuesday denounced Israel‚Äôs attack on Qatar last week, demanding ‚Äúaccountability‚Äù. Israel‚Äôs strikes on the Qatari capital on September 9 targeted Hamas leaders gathered to discuss a new US ceasefire proposal for Gaza. Five Hamas members and a Qatari security officer were killed. That strike ‚Äúwas a shocking breach of international law‚Äù, UN rights chief Volker Turk said during an urgent debate at the UN Human Rights Council about the strike. Denouncing the attack as ‚Äúan assault on regional peace and stability‚Äù, he urged ‚Äúaccountability for unlawful killings‚Äù. His words were echoed by Qatar and dozens of country representatives who took the floor during the three-hour debate. Qatari International Cooperation Minister Maryam bint Ali bin Nasser Al-Misnad slammed Israel‚Äôs ‚Äútreacherous attack‚Äù and demanded that the international community ‚Äútake practical steps to hold the aggressors accountable and prevent their impunity‚Äù. ‚ÄúThis attack was not an isolated incident, but rather was part of a broader campaign aimed at distorting Qatar‚Äôs role and obstructing its diplomatic efforts,‚Äù she said. Pakistan‚Äôs ambassador Bilal Ahmad warned that ‚Äúthis unjustifiable and unprovoked attack constitutes a dangerous escalation‚Äù. The council had announced on Monday that it would convene the 10th urgent debate since its creation in 2006, following two official requests from members of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation and of the Gulf Cooperation Council. Pakistan was among those that led the call for the urgent debate. ‚ÄòShameful‚Äô Neither Israel nor its main ally, the United States, which both disengaged from the council earlier this year, was present for the urgent debate. But Israel‚Äôs ambassador in Geneva, Daniel Meron, lambasted the meeting from the sidelines. ‚ÄúThis marks yet another shameful chapter in the Human Rights Council‚Äôs ongoing abuse,‚Äù he told journalists. He accused the council of ‚Äúserving as a platform for anti-Israel propaganda, while ignoring the brutal realities on the ground and the atrocities committed by Hamas‚Äù. There was little support for Israel‚Äôs position during the debate. European Union ambassador Deike Potzel stressed the bloc‚Äôs ‚Äúprincipled stance against terrorism in all its forms‚Äù, while underlining its ‚Äúsupport for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Qatar‚Äù and calling ‚Äúon Israel to respect international law‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe urge all parties to refrain from any actions that jeopardise mediation channels and regional stability,‚Äù she said. China‚Äôs ambassador Chen Xu said his country ‚Äúfirmly rejects and categorically condemns‚Äù the September 9 attack, which he charged was ‚Äúa deliberate attempt to derail the negotiation process‚Äù. Some of the harshest criticism came from South Africa, which has brought a case against Israel before the International Court of Justice, accusing it of committing genocide in Gaza. The attack ‚Äústrikes against the very heart of mediation processes‚Äù, ambassador Mxolisi Nkosi told the council, adding that it ‚Äúdemonstrates that Israel does not want to end its genocidal war against the Palestinian people‚Äù. ‚ÄúIt is time for the international community to demonstrate through practical countermeasures that Israel does not enjoy some form of special immunity from accountability.‚Äú

items.title_orig: Nepal appoints its first female PM after historic week of deadly protests
items.summary_orig: Former chief justice Sushila Karki, who was nominated by gen Z representatives, to lead interim government Nepal has sworn in its first female prime minister after a historic week in which widespread youth protests forced the resignation of her predecessor and the dissolving of parliament. items.title_orig: Nepal prime minister quits after deaths at protests sparked by social media ban
items.summary_orig: KP Sharma Oli resigns as police meet protests with deadly force, leaving 19 dead, and federal parliament is set alight Nepal‚Äôs prime minister has resigned after some of the worst unrest in decades rocked the country this week, set off by a ban on social media and discontent at political corruption and nepotism. KP Sharma Oli‚Äôs resignation came a day after widespread protests were met with deadly force by police, leaving 19 dead and hundreds injured. The spark for the protests was a government ban on 26 prominent social media apps, but escalated into a larger mass movement against corruption among political elites. Continue reading...
